subject: Refactor puppe-openstack-integration jobs
commit_message:
Refactor puppe-openstack-integration jobs

TL;DR, here's what we want:

openstack/puppet-openstack-integration to run:
* check:
  - all puppet3 scenarios, voting (no change)
  - all puppet4 scenarios, non-voting
* gate:
  - all puppet3 scenarios, voting (no change)
* experimental:
  - puppet3 + puppet4 + all scenarios on Xenial
* periodic:
  - drop puppet4 jobs (move them to check)

openstack/puppet-* modules to run:
* check:
  - all puppet3 scenarios, voting (no change)
* gate:
  - all puppet3 scenarios, voting (no change)
* experimental:
  - all puppet4 scenarios, non-voting
  - puppet3 + puppet4 + all scenarios on Xenial

Long version:

Previously, we used to run puppet4 jobs in experimental AND periodic
pipelines.

We noticed that puppet4 jobs are breaking quite often and periodic jobs
are not enough for us since we don't have any notification to let us
know of failures. Indeed, the jobs appear in
http://status.openstack.org/openstack-health/#/ but only when Tempest
runs. Most of the failures don't reach Tempest run and fail before.

We think that we should start running puppet4 jobs in our check
pipeline, and we chose puppet-openstack-integration as a first
iteration, since this project does not have a lot of commits.

This patch does:

In Jenkins:
* Modify puppet-openstack-integration job-template:
  - stop using {pipeline} since everything will be in gate.
  - add {job-suffix} so we can use '-nv' later.
* Add '-nv' suffix to:
  - Xenial Puppet 3 job (we consider it experimental).
  - All Puppet 4 jobs.
* Do not use '-nv' jobs for those that we consider voting (puppet3 jobs
  on trusty & centos7).

In Zuul layout:
* Create puppet-openstack-integration-jobs-all-check-nv with all puppet4 jobs
  Note: we didn't add puppet3 job on Xenial because we want to keep it
  experimental (non-voting and run on demand) for now.
* Execute puppet-openstack-integration-jobs-all-check-nv jobs in
  puppet-openstack-integration project (not much commits per day, so
  won't consume a lot of resources).
* Create puppet-openstack-integration-jobs-all-exp-nv with the same jobs
  as puppet-openstack-integration-jobs-all-check-nv but using
  experimental pipeline. These jobs will be created for Puppet modules
  CI so we can check them at demand.
* Add '-nv' suffix to all jobs that we consider non-voting, experimental
  or not.

Change-Id: I339d41e32ca6f682d6736986be351166b91cf103

Booting an instance on a net without subnet (or what is the same on a

subject: Allow force-delete irrespective of VM task_state
commit_message:
Allow force-delete irrespective of VM task_state

Cannot delete vm instance if duplicate delete requests are sent.

When user sends request to delete an instance, its task_state gets
changed to 'deleting' state. When an instance task_state is already in
'deleting' state and if at that moment the rabbitmq-server get crashed
by some reasons, then the instance task_state remains in 'deleting'
state and user won't be able to delete the instance forever.

At this moment, there is only one way to delete the instances, whose
task_state is 'deleting' state, by restarting the nova-compute
services where these instances are running.

To avoid restarting the nova-compute service manually, modified the
force-delete api to allow instance deletion irrespective of
instance task_state.

Added new instance task_state 'force-deleting' (which is set if instance
is deleted using force_delete api) to ignore duplicate force-delete
requests and still allowing retry on regular delete request.

libvirt: Use psutil and TERM to KILL backoff loop

Instead of directly trying to SIGKILL a active rsync/scp process

can shutdown in a nice manner (then wait for it to respond) and then
if it still has not responded attempt to SIGKILL it. This adds that
loop to do just this.

It also moves toward using psutil (already a requirement) to do the
process term/kill and process location work, since that library already
does this in a way that works across operating systems and ensures that
pids are not reused while the kill/term loop is active.

subject: Cells: Decrement available slots
commit_message:
Cells: Decrement available slots

On build, decrement a cell's available ram slots. Using the scheduler_count
configuration option the available capacity per cell is effectively divided
per scheduler. This prevents multiple schedulers from flooding the same cell
with build requests that exceed the capacity. Iff a scheduler has consumed
the entirety of the capacity allocated to it, begin consuming per cell
capacity reserved for other schedulers.

Scheduling larger instances will consume both the larger slot as well as
each of the smaller slots reported (e.g. a build request for a 2048 slot
will also consume two 1024 slots and four 512 slots).

Co-author: Ben Roble <ben.roble@rackspace.com>

subject: Instead of a multiprocessing queue use sockets via asyncore
commit_message:
Instead of a multiprocessing queue use sockets via asyncore

For a local process based executor usage currently to ensure
that task emitted notifications are proxied we use the multi
processing library and use its queue concept. This sadly creates
a proxy process that gets associated, and this proxy process
handles the queue and messages sent to and from it. Instead of
doing this we can instead just create a temporary local socket
using a random socket and have tasks (which are running in
different processes) use that to communicate back any emitted
notifications instead (and we can use the asyncore module to handle
the emitted notifications since it handles the lower level socket
reading, polling and dispatching).

To ensure that the socket created is somewhat secure we use a
similar process as the multi-processing library uses where we
sign all messages with a hmac that uses a one time key that only
the main process and the child process know about (and reject
any messages that do not validate using this key).

subject: Add a best-effort sudo safety check
commit_message:
Add a best-effort sudo safety check

As motivation for this; we have had two breakouts of dib in recent
memory.  One was a failure to unmount through symlinks in the core
code (I335316019ef948758392b03e91f9869102a472b9) and the other was
removing host keys on the build-system
(Ib01d71ff9415a0ae04d963f6e380aab9ac2260ce).

For the most part, dib runs unprivileged.  Bits of the core code are
hopefully well tested (modulo bugs like the first one!).  We give free
reign inside the chroot (although there is still some potential there
for adverse external affects via bind mounts).  Where we could be a
bit safer (and could have prevented at least the second of these
breakouts) is with some better checking that the "sudo" calls
*outside* the chroot at least looked sane.

This adds a basic check that we're using chroot or image paths when
calling sudo in those parts of elements that run *outside* the chroot.
Various files are updated to accomodate this check; mostly by just
ignoring it for existing code (I have not audited these calls).

Nobody is pretending this type of checking makes dib magically safe,
or removes the issues with it needing to do things as root during the
build.  But this can help find egregious errors like the key removal.

Some kernel modules take substantial time to initialize. For example,
with mpt2sas RAID driver inspection and deployment randomly fail
due to IPA starting before the driver finishes initialization.

This problem is probably impossible to solve in a generic case, as
modern Linux environment do not have a notion of "hardware is fully
initialized" moment. All hardware is essentially hotplug.

on start up waiting for at least one suitable disk to appear in inventory.

subject: RabbitMQ heartbeats for consumer threads
commit_message:
RabbitMQ heartbeats for consumer threads

Sometimes network connection between agent and RabbitMQ
becomes corrupted without agent being aware. Usually
it happen due to some networking reconfiguration. For example
changes to iptables. Because consumer connection only reads from
the socket it cannot detect broken connection and will wait
for the message forever.

This commit enables periodic heartbeats that agent sends to the
server. If RabbitMQ doesn't receive heartbeats for some time it
disconnects the client. On the other hand because heartbeat
is a write operation it lets the client to detect broken connection
as well.

Change-Id: Id326f8d3b6dce04d83472837e11342efa8eb32fe
Closes-Bug: #1583007
Partially-Implements: blueprint rabbitmq-heartbeats

At the moment, the Hyper-V driver uses the UNC path of images

According to the MS docs, this is not supported for SOFS SMB shares.

This is troublesome for the Hyper-C scenario, as Hyper-V will attempt
to modify the image ACLs, making them unusable.

The fix consists in checking if the share is local, and use the
local path in that case.

subject: Implement a Job for Mariadb Bootstrap
commit_message:
Implement a Job for Mariadb Bootstrap

Using a Job and etcd, we can signal to Kubernetes when a bootstrapping
action is in progress and when it's complete.

When an action is in progress, the pods associated with the service will
poll etcd waiting for mariadb_bootstrapped to return true and exit(1).
Kubernetes will reschedule the pods until it passes.

The bootstrap container will manage the variable by signaling etcd
that a bootstrap is in progress. After the boostrap is complete,
the Job will exit(0) and not be rescheduled.

Change-Id: I06de8ebc347de3eab9aa58e8af85d9fa76182af5

subject: [WIP] Add support for VPNaaS
commit_message:
[WIP] Add support for VPNaaS

There are a number of ways that VPNaaS support can be added to OVN. The
current VPNaaS support in neutron is built on top of the L3 router. Work
was done to decouple the VPNaaS logic from the L3 rotuer in patch:

   https://review.openstack.org/#/c/298323/

In order to reuse the existing neutron VPNaaS code base, a neutron DB
router object and an IP namespace are required. This patch, used in
conjunction with the one listed above, will allow two different types of
routers to be active: the normal OVN router and an agent based VPN
specific router. In order to distinguishing between the two types of
routers, the router name field is being used. Obviously that will need
to change.

Requiring a 2nd router for the VPN traffic is not ideal and it is not
consistent with the current neutron VPNaaS user experience today. It
may be possible to reuse the existing neutron router object created for
an OVN router and add-on the additional VPNaaS fields that are required.

added to the failed list if it contains no failed resources so that the
user only sees root-cause failed resources.

The output is a yamlish format where the key is a dot-delimited resource
name path and the value is a dict of resource information.

with mpt2sas RAID driver inspection and deployment randomly fail
due to IPA starting before the driver finishes initialization.

As much as I hate it, the only way to guarantee that the hardware is
truely initalized is to wait for it. Apparently all hardware in Linux
is treated as hotplugged, so there is no such thing as "hardware
initialization is finished". Operators can add a sleep based on their
knowledge of their hardware.
